original_data.question: A 77-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with the complaints of fever, malaise, and night sweats. She recently observed an enlargement of her axillary lymph nodes, which she examines on a weekly basis. She has a remote history of breast cancer in her 60s that was treated with radiation and chemotherapy. She also reports a history of extensive travel to Africa and a 30-pack-year history of smoking. On physical exam, several axillary lymph nodes are palpable with a large non-tender palpable mass in her right axilla measuring 10 x 8 cm. Fine-needle aspiration demonstrates what the pathologist describes as "a centroblastic and immunoblastic cell presence, suspicious for non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma (NHL)–diffuse large B cell variant". Which of the following risk factors is responsible for this patient’s condition?

model_response:
The correct answer is C. This patient's history of extensive travel to Africa and the finding of a large non-tender palpable mass in her right axilla are consistent with the diagnosis of Burkitt lymphoma. The Epstein-Barr virus is associated with this form of NHL, which is more common in individuals with immunodeficiency states, such as HIV infection, and in individuals who have undergone organ transplantation. The Epstein-Barr virus has also been associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma, Hodgkin's disease, and B cell lymphoma. The Epstein-Barr virus has also been associated with the development of Burkitt lymphoma in individuals who have received immunosuppressive therapy, such as chemotherapy and organ transplantation. The Epstein-Barr virus has also been associated with the development of Burkitt lymphoma in individuals who have received immunosuppressive therapy, such as chemotherapy and organ transplantation.

Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
A sudden unforeseen crisis that requires immediate action.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.
A feeling of general discomfort or uneasiness, an out-of-sorts feeling.
Perspiration experienced nocturnally that is unrelated to environmental temperature.
General increase in bulk of a part or organ due to CELL ENLARGEMENT and accumulation of FLUIDS AND SECRETIONS, not due to tumor formation, nor to an increase in the number of cells (HYPERPLASIA).
One of approximately 20-30 lymph nodes in chain formation that traverse the concavity of the underarm to the clavicle.
Every week.
Record and study of past events.

A primary or metastatic malignant neoplasm involving the breast. The vast majority of cases are carcinomas arising from the breast parenchyma or the nipple. Malignant breast neoplasms occur more frequently in females than in males.
Waves of oscillating electric and MAGNETIC FIELDS which move at right angles to each other and outward from the source.
The use of DRUGS to treat a DISEASE or its symptoms. One example is the use of ANTINEOPLASTIC AGENTS to treat CANCER.
Record and study of past events.
Large in quantity, range, or spatial extent.
MOVEMENT across different GEOGRAPHIC LOCATIONS.
The continent south of EUROPE, east of the ATLANTIC OCEAN and west of the INDIAN OCEAN.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
Willful or deliberate act of inhaling and exhaling SMOKE from burning substances or agents held by hand.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
One of approximately 20-30 lymph nodes in chain formation that traverse the concavity of the underarm to the clavicle.
A benign or malignant pathologic structure in any part of the body, resulting from a neoplastic accumulation of cells, inflammatory cells, or cystic changes.
The removal of tissue or fluid with a thin needle for examination under a microscope.
Physicians who assess changes in cellular or tissue structure and function to diagnose disease processes.
An activated B-lymphocyte found in the germinal centers. It has a large nucleus without clefts, finely dispersed chromatin, and a rim of basophilic cytoplasm.

Malignant lymphoma characterized by the presence of immunoblasts with uniformly round-to-oval nuclei, one or more prominent nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm. This class may be subdivided into plasmacytoid and clear-cell types based on cytoplasmic characteristics. A third category, pleomorphous, may be analogous to some of the peripheral T-cell lymphomas (LYMPHOMA, T-CELL, PERIPHERAL) recorded in both the United States and Japan.

Any of a group of malignant tumors of lymphoid tissue that differ from HODGKIN DISEASE, being more heterogeneous with respect to malignant cell lineage, clinical course, prognosis, and therapy. The only common feature among these tumors is the absence of giant REED-STERNBERG CELLS, a characteristic of Hodgkin's disease.

An aspect of personal behavior or lifestyle, environmental exposure, inborn or inherited characteristic, which, based on epidemiological evidence, is known to be associated with a health-related condition considered important to prevent.
A description of the physiological status of a patient.
